title: Do you really need to include your secured debt(i.e car payment) under a chapter13 plan to allow 2nd lien strip? Help!
question: I was told today by an attorney I had consulted in CA that I will be needing to include my car payment of $750 per mos to my chp13 plan in order for a 2nd lien strip to be possible. My car will be paid off in a year and I don't want to start from scratch and pay it in 5yrs again(even if it is lower). Besides, it is more flexible not to include this in the plan. Also, I worry about implication of car title under bankruptcy plan. Pls help clarify BK attorneys..
answers:
I have been to several bankruptcy conferences in central California & I believe the attorney you consulted was correct in saying that the Trustees require you to pay off your vehicle through the Plan.

It's a goofy system, but they all just love it in places like Sacramento & Modesto. If that is the case, I don't know that you can find away around it.

There shouldn't be a problem with you receiving the title to the vehicle once it has been paid off. In a Chapter 13, you keep all property rights & do not turn over any property to the Trustee.

Good luck!

First off, I recommend that you seek the advice of another bankruptcy attorney in your area.

I am not aware of any part of the Bankruptcy Code that says that if you do not include the car payment so that it is paid through the Chapter 13 plan, then you cannot strip a second mortgage with a Lam Motion. The benefit of including the car payment so that it is paid through the Chapter 13 plan is so you can make the payments more manageable by spreading it out over three or five years, pay the arrearages so that you can be caught up with the loan, and to do a cram down on the vehicle. I have filed bankruptcies for people where they paid their car loan outside of the Chapter 13 Bankruptcy and still did the lien strip.

I don't practice Bankruptcy in the San Jose area. It might be that there is some local rule or there is a Bankruptcy Judge in the San Jose area that won't strip the second mortgage unless you pay all secured debts through the bankruptcy. In Los Angeles, there is one Judge that won't strip your second mortgage if you are not current with it. Unless you practice bankruptcy in Los Angeles, you would never know that. You may want to contact that Chapter 13 Bankruptcy attorney again to make sure that you understood him/her correctly and ask why it is that you need to pay the car loan through the Chapter 13 plan in order to strip the second mortgage.

Best of luck to you!

It all depends on local practice. You may be forced to either include the payment through the plan OR include the amount of money you paid after the car is paid off. None of this has to do with the lien strip in a 13.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

Only in a Chapter 13 bankruptcy, and not in a chapter 7 bankruptcy, can a second mortgage be removed from your home. This is what’s commonly referred to as “stripping off” the lien.

In the past few years, strip offs have become much more common as property values in both Colorado and nationwide have substantially decreased.

How do you strip off a second mortgage? If the fair market value of your home (as of the date of the bankruptcy filing) is less than the overall mortgage balance for the 1st mortgage only, the second mortgage is deemed to be unsecured, thus allowing for such to be stripped off in a Chapter 13 bankruptcy.

For instance, if the fair market value of your house as of the date of the bankruptcy filing is $200,000, any second mortgage is considered unsecured if you still owe $220,000 on just your 1st mortgage. For many clients, these two numbers will be very close in which case I recommend that either a realtor conduct a Comparative Market Analysis (CMA) or, for situations where this could be a contested issue in Bankruptcy Court, a formal appraisal.

What this entails is that, throughout the Chapter 13 payment plan, the amount owed to the second mortgagee will be added to any other unsecured debt (such as credit card debt or medical bills) and only a small portion of this overall unsecured debt is typically paid back to the unsecured creditors, depending on your particular circumstances. At the same time, unlike with any remaining secured creditors, you will not required to pay back the second mortgagee the amount of its claim, and no interest accrues either since the claim is no longer secured.

Please be aware that the second mortgage cannot be stripped off if even $1 of debt remains secured. Going back to my previous example involving the $200,000 house, no strip off will occur on a second mortgage if the amount owed on the first mortgage (again, as of the date of the bankruptcy filing) is even just below $200,000.

When the chapter 13 plan is successfully completed, the Bankruptcy Court will enter a discharge order which will include the portion of unpaid unsecured debt, including the stripped off second mortgage. Once the bankruptcy discharge order is entered, the second mortgage is deemed permanently extinguished.

With that said, it is critical for the bankruptcy debtor to successfully make all chapter 13 plan payments to complete the plan. Only after this time will the court enter the final discharge order stripping off the second mortgage. I always advise clients of the disastrous impact of an unsuccessful chapter 13 plan: if the case is dismissed (almost always for failure to make plan payments), all unsecured debts, such as the almost stripped off mortgage and credit card debts are retroactively revived, including accrued interest and penalties.
